title: Not all soda sales are down since Philly passed tax
text:
Not all soda sales are down since Philly passed tax   5:00 PM EDT 2 Share Joseph N. DiStefano writes about Philadelphia-area enterprise, and the people and money that make it go. 
"We are offering the products and package sizes working families are more able to afford because we believe this will give our retail and foodservice partners the best chance to succeed in this challenging environment and will minimize the chance of product going out-of-date," Pepsico spokeswoman Jennifer Ryan told me. 
"Larger package" sales are down "more than 50%," and even more at some grocers, Pepsi says. But overall, the Philadelphia tax doesn't seem to be hurting Pepsico too much: " Pepsi’ 
Even though it doesn't seem to be hurting regionally, by that count, Pepsi is still threatening to "eliminate 80-100 positions in Philadelphia over the next few months" if the tax isn't reversed, and promising "to bring people back to work" if the city caves in. 
At Coke, sales are up for the smaller sized products: "In 2016, 7.5-oz mini-cans grew 9% and 1.25 liter bottles grew 9.5% and they are still growing this year, according to a statement by Fran McGorry, president and general manager of the Tri-State Operating Unit, Coca-Cola Refreshments. 
McGorry wouldn't provide data on regional sales-volume changes to other Coke products.
